Fig. 1 Fig. 2 HAADF-STEM images and Au elemental distribution maps (yellow) of Au/TiO2-400 (a-b), Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 (c-d), Au/Pr1Ti1Ox-400 (e-f) and Au/Pr2Ti1Ox-400 (g-h) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the Au/TiO2-400, Au/PraTibOx-400 (a) and Au/PraTibOx-800 (b) catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 X-ray Photoemission spectra(XPS) of Pr 3d (a), Ti 2p (b), Au 4 f (c), O 1 s (d) of the Au/TiO2-400 and Au/PraTibOx-400 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Bar graph of Ti 2p & Pr 3d (a) and Au 4 f (b) spectra of the Au/TiO2-400 and Au/PraTibOx-400 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR (a) and O2-TPD (b) analysis of the Au/TiO2-400, Au/PraTibOx-400. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 CO conversion (a) over the Au/TiO2-400, Au/PraTibOx-400 (a) and Au/PraTibOx-800 catalysts (60 vol% CO2 + 1 vol% CO+ 0.5 vol% O2 + 0.5 vol% H2O+ N2 balance，GHSV=60000 mL·gcat −1·h−1); the CO conversion rate (b), TOF values (c) and activation energy (d) of Au/TiO2-400 and Au/PraTibOx-400 catalysts (60 vol% CO2 +1 vol% CO+0.5 vol% O2 +0.5 vol% H2O+N2 balance，GHSV=240000 mL·gcat −1·h−1). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The comparison of CO conversion (a), CO conversion rate at 75 ℃ (b) and activation energy (c) of Au/TiO2-400 and Au/PraTibOx-400 catalysts in the feed with CO2 (60 vol% CO2 +1 vol% CO+0.5 vol% O2 +0.5 vol% H2O+ N2 balance, GHSV=60000 mL·gcat −1·h−1); and without CO2 (98 vol% N2 + 1 vol% CO+ 0.5 vol% O2 + 0.5 vol% H2O, GHSV=240000 mL·gcat −1·h−1), Solid. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The steady-state test at a constant temperature of 100 ℃ of the Au/TiO2-400 and Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 catalysts: (a) No CO2 (98 vol% N2 +1 vol% CO+ 0.5 vol% O2 + 0.5 vol% H2O, GHSV=120000 mL·gcat −1·h−1) and (b) Rich CO2 (60 vol% CO2 +1 vol% CO+ 0.5 vol% O2 + 0.5 vol% H2O+ N2 balance, GHSV=120000 mL·gcat −1·h−1). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 HAADF-STEM images and Au elemental distributions maps (yellow) of fresh and used Au/TiO2-400 (a), and Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 (b) catalysts. In this study, based on the characteristic of lanthanide in oxygen storage capacity, a series of PraTibOx composite supports with different mole ratios of Pr to Ti and the corresponding Au catalysts were prepared - to investigate the oxidation of CO under CO2-rich atmosphere with lean oxygen content. A significant promotion in CO conversion rate over the catalyst with a molar ratio of Pr:Ti = 1:2 and a very high catalytic stability was also obtained. The addition of optimal Pr will make smaller gold particles, provide higher capacity in surface reactive oxygen releasing at low temperatures and weaken the deposition of carbonates in CO2-rich atmosphere. However, more Pr will strongly interact with gold, which leads to the majority of Au+ species in the catalysts and thus lower the catalytic activity. This study may provide a potential application of rare earth elements in sealed CO2-laser. Graphical Abstract The addition of optimal amount of praseodymium will make smaller gold particles, provide higher capacity in surface reactive oxygen releasing at low temperatures and weaken the deposition of carbonates in CO2-rich atmosphere, so that the CO conversion rate and the catalytic stability of Au/TiO2 is greatly enhanced in CO2-rich atmosphere with lean oxygen content. ga1 Keywords Au catalyst Praseodymium doped TiO2 CO oxidation CO2-rich atmosphere Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The oxidation of carbon monoxide reaction has high application value in many practical problems, such as the treatment of environmental pollution [1,2], the development of CO gas masks [3], and the elimination of CO in CO2 lasers [4], etc. The life of sealed CO2 laser can be extending by recombining CO molecules and oxygen which decomposed from CO2 in the working process. In this case, the main challenges for the catalyst will work in an atmosphere with high CO2 level and stoichiometric or less O2/CO ratio. Some supported noble metal catalysts, such as Pt-, Pd-, Rh-, and Ru -based catalysts have been studied as promising catalysts for use in sealed CO2 lasers, However, they failed in practical applications due to their relatively poor activity at temperatures lower than 100 ℃ and to their quick deactivation [5]. On the other hand, supported gold catalysts have exhibited extremely high catalytic activity for CO oxidation, especially at lower temperatures [6], showing great potential to serve in CO2 laser. Many satisfactory results were then obtained [7,8], including our work [4]. Due to the unique electronic layer structure and lanthanide shrinkage characteristics, rare earth metals show high performance in enhancing the thermal stability and mechanical strength of catalyst support, which improves the oxygen storage capacity of the catalyst and adjusts its surface acidity and basicity. For instance, Reddy et al. [9] prepared Ce0.8Pr0.2O2-δ using the co-precipitation method. They deduced that the doping of Pr promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. In addition, under the synergistic effect of Re3+/Re4+ Re = Ce, Pr) reducing electron pairs, the oxygen fluidity was improved, and thus the catalytic oxidation activity of the catalyst was enhanced. Moreover, the doping of Pr promotes the improvement of the thermal stability of the catalyst and avoids the sintering of the catalyst after calcination at 800 ℃. The study of Bäumer et al.[10] showed that Pr3+/Pr4+ accounts for approximately 1:1 in the most stable praseodymium oxide (Pr6O11), and therefore the praseodymium oxide theoretically has a very high redox capacity. In this paper, praseodymium was used as a promoter to modify TiO2, and several of PraTibOx composite metal oxides with different molar ratios (Pr/Ti = a/b) were prepared using the sol-gel method. 0.5 wt% Au was then loaded on these prepared PraTibOx support materials using the deposition precipitation method. The oxidation of carbon monoxide in a simulated atmosphere of CO2 laser and the interaction between praseodymium and titanium were studied with an attempt to find an optimal catalyst composition and clarify the catalytic role of praseodymium to Au-based catalyst in such a CO2-rich atmosphere. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of TiO2 and PraTibOx Titanium dioxide and praseodymium titanium composite oxide supports (denoted by PraTibOx) were obtained using the sol-gel method. The detailed steps are as follows: adding 1.5 mL of tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT) to 200 mL of anhydrous ethanol at room temperature and stirring for 15 min, then adding a certain amount of 1 mol/L ethanolic solution of praseodymium nitrate (0, 1.08, 2.16, 4.32, and 8.64 mL) drop by drop and stirring for 15 min, and finally adding 0.6 mL of concentrated ammonia and mechanically stirring for 24 h. After stirring, the obtained sols were aged for a certain period of time, followed by drying at 75 °C for 10 h and roasting at 400 ℃ or 800 ℃ in air for 4 h. The resulting oxide supports were denoted by TiO2-400 and PraTibOx-400, TiO2-800 and PraTibOx-800, with molar ratios of a:b = 0, 1:4, 1:2, 1:1, and 2:1. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Au/TiO2 and Au/PraTibOx catalysts Au was loaded on TiO2 and PraTibOx using our previous method, that is, a modified deposition–precipitation (MDP) method [11]. The theoretical gold loading of all the catalysts used in this study is 0.5 wt%. A certain amount of chloroauric acid solution (9.56 mg/mL) was first taken in a beaker. An appropriate amount of deionized water and 1 mol/L potassium hydroxide solution were then added so that the pH of the mixed solution becomes in the range of 9–10. Afterwards, the support powder was slowly added to the solution and sonicated to make the gold precursor evenly dispersed on the support. The catalyst precursor was then soaked in ammonia overnight, filtered, washed, dried, and finally calcined at 300 °C in air. The resulting gold-based catalysts are denoted by Au/TiO2-400 and Au/PraTibOx-400, Au/TiO2-800 and Au/PraTibOx-800 based on the corresponding supports of TiO2 and PraTibOx with calacination temperatures of 400 and 800 ℃, respectively. The XPS analysis shows that the surface atomic ratio of Pr: Ti for Au/Pr1Ti4Ox, Au/Pr1Ti2Ox, Au/Pr1Ti1Ox, Au/Pr2Ti1Ox are 1:3.5, 1:1.9, 0.8:1 and 2.8:1, respectively. This value are close to the desired value (during synthesis), which demonstrates the effectiveness of controlling the Pr:Ti using a sol-gel method. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal phases of the supports were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) performed on a D8 Focus diffractometer (Bruker) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 ˚A) operating at 40 mA and 40 kV. The catalysts particles were crushed and placed in a holder, then scanned over the range of 2θ from 10 to 70 ° at a rate of 5.0°/min. Depending on digital powder XRD data, quantitative phase analyses of our samples Au/ZrO2-650 and Au/ZrO2-800 samples with mixed structures were conducted using an adaptation of the Rietveld method. The gold content of all the catalysts was measured using an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) with Agilent 5110 analyzer. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were determined at − 196 ℃ on a Micromeritics ASAP2020HD with pretreatment at 200 ℃ under vacuum for 4 h. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation was used to calculate the specific surface area. The pore size distribution was obtained from the desorption branch using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were performed using an FEI Talos F200X at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) measurements were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). All the binding energies were calibrated with the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed in Bel Cata II (BEL Japan). The prepared catalysts were first pretreated in He at 200 ℃ for 1.5 h and then treated in 20% O2/He for 30 min at 350 ℃. After the temperature was cooled to room temperature, the 10% H2/He was exposed for 60 min until the baseline stabilized.The analysis was conducted in the stream from room temperature to 800 °C with a ramp rate of 10°/min. A temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD, O2-TPD) testing was performed using Mac Instruments AutoChem II chemisorber. The prepared catalysts were first pretreated at 200 ℃ for 1.5 h. After the temperature was reduced to room temperature, the probe molecules were adsorbed for 60 min，then the argon purge for 30 min. After the baseline was stabilized, the temperature was tested from room temperature to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10°/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was finally used to record the experimental results. 2.3 Catalyst evaluations The catalytic performance of the catalyst was evaluated by the oxidation reaction of carbon monoxide in a carbon dioxide rich atmosphere. A U-shaped glass tube, having an inner diameter of 8 mm, was used for the experiment, and the reaction temperature was precisely controlled using an intelligent temperature controller. The reaction products were analyzed online by the Agilent 7820 A gas chromatograph. 100 ± 10 mg of catalyst was weighed and placed in a U-shaped glass tube for activity experimental evaluation. The total reaction gas rate was 100 mL/min, and the feed was composed of 60 vol% CO2, 1 vol% CO, 0.5 vol% O2, 0.5 vol% H2O, and 38 vol% N2. The reaction temperature was in the range of 50---− 400 ℃ with an interval of 50 ℃. The CO conversion (XCO) was quantified using an area normalization method and determined by the degradation of CO gas by Eq. (1): (1) X CO = CO in − CO out CO in × 100 % where XCO is the conversion of carbon monoxide, COout is its export concentration, and COin is its concentration in the feed gas. The turnover frequencies (TOF) were calculated as: (2) TOF ( s − 1 ) = X CO × F CO × M Au W cat × X Au × D Au where XCO is the conversion of carbon monoxide, FCO is the carbon monoxide flow rate per unit time, MAu is the molar mass of gold (197 g/mol), Wcat is the catalyst mass, DAu is the dispersion of gold in the catalyst, and XAu is the actual gold loading of the used catalyst. The metal dispersion (DAu) was calculated as: (3) DAu = 6M Au/ αAuρNA dVS where MAu denotes the molar mass of gold (0.197 kg/mol), aAu(8.7 × 10−20 m2) denotes the average effective area of the Au atom, ρ (1.932 × 104 kg/m3) denotes the density of gold, NA denotes the Avogadro number, and dVS denotes the volume surface diameter [12] calculated according to Eq. (4): Dvs = ∑di 3/∑di 2 where di is the measured diameter of a gold cluster by TEM. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the Au/TiO2 and Au/PraTibOx catalysts It can be seen from the TEM images of Fig. 1a, d, g, and j that the Au/TiO2-400 catalyst has a octahedral nanocrystalline structure. The Au/PraTibOx-400 catalyst has a layered structure, which is more compact compared with the above catalysts. The b, e, h, and k HRTEM images show that the (101) crystal plane of octahedral TiO2 nanocrystals and the (111) crystal plane of gold are mainly. exposed in the newly prepared Au/TiO2-400 catalyst [13]. In addition, the (111) crystal plane of Pr6O11 was found in Au/Pr1Ti1Ox-400 and Au/Pr2Ti1Ox-400, which indicaties that praseodymium-titanium composite oxides are obtained. According to the literature, the activity of catalytic CO oxidation reaction increases with the decrease of the size of gold nanoparticles [14] and the optimal size is in the range of 2–5 nm [15,16]. The size of the gold nanoparticles on each catalyst was then statistically analyzed, as shown in Fig. 1c, i, and l. When praseodymium was introduced, the size of gold nanoparticles was reduced from 5.3 nm to approximately 3.5 nm, which indicates that praseodymium species have positive effects on confining gold nanoparticles. Although no clear gold nanoparticles can be observed in the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 catalyst, a more uniform dispersion of gold nanoparticles can be seen by the mapping of Au elements in Fig. 2(d). Therefore, it can be deduced that gold may be dispersed as nanoclusters [17,18] in supports (∼ 2 nm) and cannot be detected using HRTEM [19]. XRD characterization was used to determine the crystal structure of the catalyst. The Au/TiO2-400 catalyst can be classified as anatase structure (tetragonal crystal system, JCPDS 84–1258), as shown in Fig. 3b. On the contrary, the Au/PraTibOx-400 series catalysts have only a broad diffraction peak (26°−33°), and therefore they are classified as amorphous phase structures. This is also similar to the results of CeO2-TiO2 prepared using the sol-gel method proposed by Liang et al. [20]. Fig. 3(b) presents the transformation of the crystal structure of the Au/ PraTibOx − 800 series catalyst from an amorphous structure at 400 °C to a praseodymium-titanium composite oxide crystal structure. This may be attributed to the fact that at lower calcination temperatures, Au/PraTibOx-400 series catalysts have both oxides and hydroxides, and as the calcination temperature increases, the hydroxides in the bulk phase lose their hydroxyl groups to oxides. In addition, with the praseodymium elements increased, the crystal structure changed as: Pr4Ti9O24 (JCPDS 83–2304) → Pr4Ti9O24 & Pr2Ti2O7 (JCPDS 35–0267) → Pr6O11 (JCPDS 42–1121) & PrO2 (JCPDS 24–1006) [21]. The physical structure properties of all the samples were studied using the nitrogen adsorption and desorption techniques. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of two samples of Au/Pr1Ti4Ox-400 and Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 in Fig. 4 are typical type IV isotherms, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures. Other samples did not show hysteresis at P/P0 of 0.4–0.6 in the isotherms but with clear loop in relative P/P0 range higher than 0.8, which indicates the absence of mesopores and the presence of packed larger pores. in the prepared catalysts. It can be deduced from Table 1 that the molar ratio and calcination temperature have a large effect on the specific surface area of the catalysts, especially for the Au/PraTibOx-800 catalysts in the range of 1–8 m2 ·g−1. When the molar ratio of the praseodymium and titanium elements is more than the half, the specific surface area of the catalyst does not change, even if the calcination temperature of the support is increased. This indicates that the Au/Pr1Ti1Ox and Au/Pr2Ti1Ox catalysts have a non-porous stable structure before calcination. To clarify the electronic interactions between Ti and Pr, the valence changes in Ti and Pr were studied. Fig. 5a and b show the Pr 3d and Ti 2p XPS spectra of the Au/PraTibOx-400 and Au/TiO2-400 catalysts, respectively. According to the systematic study of Baumer et al. [22], the two groups of orbital spin splitting peaks at 930.2–951.9 eV, and 934.4–955.2 eV belong to Pr3+ and Pr4+, respectively. The peak at 949 eV is related to the oxidation degree of praseodymium (PrO2), which is attributed to the correlation of Pr4+. The Ti 2p3/2 spectrum in Fig. 5b is deconvoluted into two peaks at 459.1–464.3 eV, and 457.2–462.2 eV, that are assigned to the Ti4+ and Ti3+ states, respectively. The ratio of these peaks can be used as a semi-quantitative probe for the amount of Pr4+ in the oxides. Fig. 6a shows the changes of Ti3+, Pr3+ and Pr4+ content with the mixing of Pr: Ti from 1:4–1:2 and 2:1. It can be seen that the ratios of Ti3+ and Pr4+ follow the same trend, while Au/Pr2Ti1Ox has the highest amount of Ti3+ (0.62) and Pr4+ (0.7), also corresponding to the lowest amount of Pr3+ (0.30). This can be explained by the interaction between Pr and Ti. It is known that in TiO2 the main cations are Ti4+, while in PrOx the number of cations is Pr3+. As Ti4+ (0.745 Å) is smaller than Pr3+ (1.266 Å), it should have a stronger affinity to electrons, when both Ti4+ and Pr3+ coordinate with O (Ti-O-Pr). Electrons of O may tend to move to Ti, leading to the reduction of Ti4+→Ti3+ (accompanied by the creation of O vacancies). O Simultaneously attracts more electrons from Pr for compensation result in the oxidation of Pr3+ to Pr4+. Fig. 5c and Fig. 6b show the Au 4 f spectra of the catalysts and the quantitative analysis of XPS, respectively. The 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2 orbital binding energies of Au0 are respectively attributed to 86.8 eV and 83.1 eV, and the 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2 orbital binding energies of Au+ are attributed to 87.7 eV and 83.8 eV, respectively[23,24]. In the in-situ measurement, the X-ray irradiation can modify the oxidation state of gold, which depends on the particle size. As stated by Jiang et. al [25], molecular oxygen can be activated on both bulk Au foil and Au nanoparticles supported on the TiO2 (110) surface by X-ray irradiation to produce oxidic Au. Similar results were observed by van Bokhoven et al. [26,27]. However, it is important to mention that the oxidic Au in the NPs on TiO2(110) not bulk Au foil is not stable and can be readily reduced under X-ray irradiation. This reduction behavior for the nanoparticle sample is ascribed to the well-known facile reducibility of the TiO2 support [28,29]. It can be seen from Fig. 5c that the metallic Au is dominant over Au/TiO2, which presents gold nanoparticles with a mean diameter of 5.3 nm (Fig. 1). This result is consistent with those obtained in [25–27]. On the other hand, the oxidic Au increases with the increase of the Pr content. Especially for Au/Pr1Ti1Ox and Au/Pr2Ti1Ox, oxidic Au is dominant. Ther gold nanoparticles sizes for these two samples are mainly in the range of 1.5–6 nm with a mean diameter of 3.4 ± 0.3 nm, which indicaties the influence of Pr addition in chemical state of Au. Wu et al.[30] and Yates et al. [31] demonstrated that the zero-valent gold plays a key role in the CO oxidation reaction by means of in situ characterization. The analysis of the XPS results shows that the introduction of praseodymium increases the content of positive valence gold, which indicates that the addition of praseodymium enhances the electronic interaction between the particle and the oxide support. This makes the Au/Pr1Ti1Ox-400 and Au/Pr2Ti1Ox-400 catalysts exist mainly in the Au+ form, which is one of the reasons for the poor CO reaction rates of the above two catalysts. Fig. 5(d) shows the O 1 s spectra of all the catalysts. O 1 s can be classified into three peaks: 529.5 eV attributed to lattice oxygen species (Ti-O, Pr-O), 531.5 eV attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen species (O2-, Pr-OH, Ti-OH), and 533.5 eV attributed to adsorbed water molecules [32,33]. When the praseodymium-titanium molar ratio increases, the percentage of lattice oxygen species gradually decreases and the percentage of surface adsorbed oxygen species gradually increases, which is similar to the O 1 s spectrum in Au/Pr6O11 [1,34]. The redox properties of the catalysts were investigated using the H2-TPR and O2-TPD technique. The hydrogen consumption is roughly divided into two regions ( Fig. 7a): the low temperature region (50–200 °C) and the high temperature region (250–550 °C). The low temperature region is attributed to the reduction of surface active oxides (Au-Ox→Au0, PrTiOx at the Au perimeter) and the high temperature region is attributed to the reduction of lattice oxygen (PrOx, TiOx or PrTiOx). The results show that the introduction of praseodymium decreases the reduction temperature of the surface active oxide, which facilitates the release of oxygen atoms at low temperatures, while the excess of praseodymium makes the reduction peak shift to high temperatures, suggesting an increase in the electron interaction between gold and the support. In other words, the introduction of excessive praseodymium is not conducive to the reduction of gold species. Fig. 7(b) reflects the adsorption and desorption ability of the catalysts to oxygen. The analysis of the figure shows that the temperatures at which the Au/TiO2, Au/Pr1Ti2Ox, and Au/Pr2Ti1Ox catalysts start to show desorption signals are 150, 50, and 300 °C, respectively. Therefore, the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalyst is more likely to adsorb and release oxygen at low temperatures, which is beneficial to improve the conversion of carbon monoxide. 3.2 Catalytic performance The CO oxidation reaction was carried out in CO2-rich atmosphere. The CO conversions at 100 °C in descending order are: Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 > Au/TiO2-400 > Au/Pr1Ti4Ox-400 > Au/Pr1Ti4Ox-800 > Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-800 > Au/Pr1Ti1Ox-400 > Au/Pr1Ti1Ox-800 > Au/Pr2Ti1Ox-400 > Au/Pr2Ti1Ox-800. Based on the obtained results, the catalyst was selected in this paper for a further study after calcination at 400 °C. The corresponding CO conversion is shown in Fig. 8a. The CO reaction rate per gram of gold on all the catalysts was calculated based on the results of ICP ( Table 2) and CO conversion tests, as shown in Fig. 8b. The highest reaction rate of 10.6 mol∙gAu∙h−1 was obtained for the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 catalyst at 100 °C, followed by the Au/TiO2-400 catalyst (9.6 mol∙gAu∙h−1) and the Au/Pr1Ti4Ox-400 catalyst (6.3 mol∙gAu∙h−1), while the Au/Pr2Ti1Ox-400 (0.16 mol∙gAu∙h−1) and Au/Pr1Ti1Ox-400 (0.13 mol∙gAu∙h−1) catalysts had the lowest reaction rate. Based on the TEM observation results for four catalysts (Figs. 1 and 2), the TOF numbers were calculated as shown in Fig. 8c. The highest TOF value of (25.26 ×10−2 s−1) was obtained for the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 catalyst at 100 °C, followed by the Au/TiO2-400 (19.87 ×10−2 s−1), Au/Pr2Ti1Ox ( 0.42 ×10−2 s1), Au/Pr1Ti1Ox ( 0.17 ×10−2 s−1) catalysts. The activation energy of each catalyst in the CO2-rich atmosphere was measured in the order of 20% conversion as shown in Fig. 8d: Au/Pr1Ti2Ox (29.6 KJ·mol−1) < Au/TiO2 (37.8 KJ·mol−1) < Au/Pr1Ti4Ox (39.1 KJ·mol−1) < Au/Pr2Ti1Ox (45.6 KJ·mol−1) < Au/Pr1Ti1Ox (48.6 KJ·mol−1). It can be seen that the activity data of the CO conversation rates, the TOF numbers and the activation energy values are basically consistent, which shows that the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox-400 catalyst is most active. In summary, the introduction of a certain amount of praseodymium in titanium dioxide can significantly improve the CO reaction rate, which is mainly attributed to the reduction of the gold particle size and the improvement of surface reactive oxygen release capacity at low temperatures. 3.3 Catalytic stability All the catalysts involved in this test were prepared using oxide supports calcined at 400 ℃. It can be seen from Fig. 9a that although the high CO2 concentration atmosphere has a negative effect on the CO conversion, there is a difference in its hindering effect on each catalyst. Using the results of the data at 75 °C, the conversion rate of rich (no) CO2 was calculated to decrease by only 1.9 times for the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalyst, while it decreased by 6.1 times for the Au/TiO2 catalyst and 35.9 times for the Au/Pr1Ti4Ox catalyst. This indicates that a suitable molar ratio is beneficial to improve the stability of the catalyst. It can be deduced from the activation energy results in Fig. 8d, Fig. 9c, and Table 2 that the activation energy is significantly higher due to the presence of high CO2 concentration, which hinders the CO2 desorption step to some extent. To study the influence of the high concentration CO2 atmosphere on the stability performance of the catalysts, the Au/TiO2 and Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalysts were selected and tested for 24 h at 100 ℃. It can be seen from Fig. 10 that the Au/TiO2 and Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalystshad high stability under the CO2-free atmosphere test, and the activity only decreased by 4% after 24 h of stable test. The Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalyst remained relatively stable when tested in a CO2-rich atmosphere. However, the conversion of the Au/TiO2 catalyst sharply decreased, and the conversion rate decreased by 43% after 24 h of stable test. According to the literature [23,35,36], the deactivation of Au/TiO2 catalysts is mainly attributed to the accumulation of carbonates and the growth of gold nanoparticles. The HAADF-STEM plots in Fig. 11 show no significant change in size before and after the reaction of Au/TiO2 (5.3 nm vs 5.2 nm) and Au/Pr1Ti2Ox (∼2 nm vs ∼ 2 nm) catalysts. Therefore, the variation of gold nanoparticle size is not the reason for the low stability of the Au/TiO2 catalysts in CO2-rich atmosphere. It can be deduced from Figs. 9 and 10 that the high concentration of CO2 atmosphere will have some negative effect on the stability of the catalyst. Therefore, the CO2 adsorption and desorption capacity of the catalyst was tested using the CO2-TPD-MS technique. In Fig. 12a, 50–120 °C is attributed to the weakly adsorbed CO2 on the surface, while 200–600 °C is attributed to the decomposition of carbonate species [23]. The two catalysts showed CO2 desorption peaks at 270 °C, while Au/TiO2 had a higher peak intensity, which indicates that the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalyst surface was less prone to accumulation of carbonate species. In other words, the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalyst is weak to CO2 adsorption, which is beneficial to maintain high stability even under high CO2 concentration atmosphere. The FT-IR characterization was used to detect carbonate species on the catalyst surface after stability testing. The 3400 cm−1 in Fig. 12(b) is attributed to the stretching vibration of the hydroxyl group (ν OH) and the 1200–1800 cm−1 is attributed to the carbonate species [37]. 1249 cm−1 is attributed to the CO2 adsorption on TiO2 (ν OCO), 1380 cm−1 and 1480 cm−1 respectively correspond to the stretching vibrations of carboxylate (νs COO and νas COO)[38], while 1632 cm−1 and 1667 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of carbonate (ν CO3) or bicarbonate (ν HCO3)[13,39]. The peak intensities at 1632 cm−1 and 1667 cm−1 were stronger in the Au/TiO2 catalysts. This indicates that the adsorbed CO2 is converted to carbonates that are tightly attached to the catalyst surface and obstruct the active site, which results in a low reaction stability of the Au/TiO2 catalyst. This is also consistent with the CO2-TPD-MS characterization results. TG-MS characterization was used to detect the carbon accumulation of the catalyst after stability testing. The 50–120 °C in Fig. 12c can be attributed to the desorption of surface water molecules, and the 120–400 °C can be due to the desorption of oxygen species (carbonates, lattice oxygen or hydroxyl groups). Fig. 12d shows the CO2 mass spectrometry curves during thermogravimetry. Both catalysts started to desorb from 100 °C, and the CO2 desorption signal of the Au/TiO2 catalyst sharply increased compared with the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalyst, which was due to the decomposition of carbonate species on the catalyst surface. It can be deduced from the CO2-TPD-MS characterization results that the CO2 molecules physically adsorbed on the surface do not occupy the active sites. On the contrary, the carbonate-like species formed on the catalyst surface cover the active sites, which decrease the overall catalyst activity. It is important to mention that in contrast to the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox sample, Au/Pr1Ti4Ox shows a decrease in activity, which is even less active than Au/TiO2 in CO2-rich gas. It is well known that for CO oxidation, the support-Au interface between the oxide support and the Au nanoparticles plays a dominating role [40,41]. Both Au species and the active oxygen species on the Au/TiO2 are considered to be involved in oxygen activation, which intrinsically determines the catalytic activity. It can be seen from Fig. 3b that the structures of Pr-containing species (or the coordinated environment of Pr) in all the corresponding samples are different. This directly leads to the clear difference in the environment of active sites, the ratio of Au0 to Au+ and the ratio of three types of O species, as shown in Fig. 5. The XPS patterns for the sample of Au/Pr1Ti4Ox are closer to that of the Au/TiO2 sample, but with more Au+ species. In other words, compared with Au/TiO2, a similar amount of carbonate-like species formed on the Au/Pr1Ti4Ox sample may cover the active sites, and more Au+ species in the sample lead to an less active catalyst. Therefore, the catalytic performance of the Pr-doped Au catalysts is the result of the environment of active sites, which greatly varies and does not linearly correlate with the amount of Pr. 4 Conclusions In this paper, the catalytic performance and stability of the Au/TiO2 catalyst in carbon monoxide oxidation reaction under CO2-rich atmosphere were improved by introducing the praseodymium element. The reaction rates were Au/Pr1Ti2Ox (10.6 mol·gAu·h−1) > Au/TiO2 (9.6 mol·gAu·h−1) > Au/Pr1Ti4Ox (6.3 mol·gAu·h−1) > Au/Pr2Ti1Ox (0.16 mol·gAu·h−1) > Au/Pr1Ti1Ox (0.13 mol·gAu·h−1). The molar ratio of the praseodymium and titanium elements has a greater effect on the reaction activity, which is mainly attributed to the excess of praseodymium elements that will strengthen the electronic interaction between the gold and the support. It can be deduced from the XPS results that gold was mostly present in the Au+ state in the Au/Pr2Ti1Ox and Au/Pr1Ti1Ox catalysts, which makes the reactivity poor. Moreover, the TEM and HRTEM showed that the introduction of rare earth metal praseodymium is beneficial to the generation of small size gold nanoparticles. Furthermore, during the CO oxidation reaction in CO2-rich atmosphere, CO2 will adsorb on the catalyst surface to generate carbonate species that are weakly adsorbed on the surface of the Au/Pr1Ti2Ox catalysts compared with the Au/TiO2 catalysts. It is also easy to desorb at low temperature, so that it maintains high stability performance even under high concentration of CO2 atmosphere. Finally, it was demonstrated that the introduction of a moderate amount of praseodymium element in the CO oxidation reaction in CO2-rich atmosphere reduces the influence of CO2 on the reaction activity and stability of the catalyst. This provides a novel approach for the development and application of rare earth elements. coredata.dc:description: In this study, based on the characteristic of lanthanide in oxygen storage capacity, a series of PraTibOx composite supports with different mole ratios of Pr to Ti and the corresponding Au catalysts were prepared - to investigate the oxidation of CO under CO2-rich atmosphere with lean oxygen content. A significant promotion in CO conversion rate over the catalyst with a molar ratio of Pr:Ti = 1:2 and a very high catalytic stability was also obtained. The addition of optimal Pr will make smaller gold particles, provide higher capacity in surface reactive oxygen releasing at low temperatures and weaken the deposition of carbonates in CO2-rich atmosphere. However, more Pr will strongly interact with gold, which leads to the majority of Au+ species in the catalysts and thus lower the catalytic activity. This study may provide a potential application of rare earth elements in sealed CO2-laser.
coredata.dc:title: The advantage of praseodymium doped TiO2 composite as the support of Au catalysts for CO oxidation in CO2-rich atmosphere
